Started off with the Salumi appetizer which was phenomenal. The duck was my favorite, absolutely mouth watering. My main course was the Pork Loin, it was basically the best pork I had ever tasted. It was like eating candy, masterfully cooked and prepared. I closed things off with the Chocolate souffle with pistachio sauce which was so good that it was just WRONG. Going to Cure was an amazing experience. Kudos to everyone on the staff for running such an amazing establishment.

WX4VjkvL79HBY86XsnKiNQ.text: Best food I've had in Pittsburgh- my husband and I had the strawberry gazpacho, salumi plate, duck and tete de cochon.  Who knew a pig's head could be so delicious?  Great, casual atmosphere, and I also liked the background music very much.  Perhaps a bid warm at the "bar" seating next to the open kitchen.  Wonderful, helpful, friendly service.  Will definitely return soon!

wUBxzuWphcP63_PWcXgnNA.text: Loved it. Great food. Quality ingredients. Fantastic service. Friendly place.

dq7boSQOUYuBx9C4geQWlQ.text: We felt that Cure was good, but not spectacular. We were excited to go and maybe all of the hype set us up for disappointment. Since they are no longer BYOB, we bought two bottles of wine and would have preferred some more affordable choices. The menu also seemed overpriced. Among four of us, we had the salumi, roast chicken, sweet pea ravioli, wall-eyed pike, the squab and the chicken breast with chorizo. The presentation of the dishes was beautiful and the food was all good. One of our guests wanted a salad, but doesn't like goat cheese and they wouldn't make it for her, without.  I understand "no substitutions", but that seemed a bit ridiculous.  The place is attractive, but the high tin ceiling makes the acoustics terrible.  The noise level is very high and it's hard to converse. We eat out regularly and love many local places...Ave B, Spoon, Salt to name a few.  We won't be headed back to Cure. It was good, but nothing memorable.

r-wxlGpubD6o4PqBBMimOg.text: Everyone has their own idea about what "fine dining" means.  For me, its where both the food and the service contribute equally to the dining experience.  Enter Cure.  Nothing better than being dressed in a pair of jeans (OK, designer jeans) and a tee, and enjoying a thoughtfully prepared and executed meal.  And in conjunction with that awesome food,  the service doesn't miss a beat.    Lawrenceville is the mecca for Pittsburgh's burgeoning restaurant business.  While I was only visiting, this neighborhood is clearly the hipster hangout.  Couldn't think of a better neighborhood for this terrific expansion to the Burgh dining scene.    While the menu does spotlight the things that carnivores covet,  there are more than enough offerings for vegetarians & pescatarians ( I was there with both)   The charcuterie sampler with homemade salumis,  cured meat and an awesome nduja is served with house made mustards and pickles.     Two varieties of raw oysters were were displayed on ice with fresh seaweed  and mignonette.   Our vegetarians ordered roasted beets  with lemon labneh and the "bread & butter" which came with roasted garlic  and some fried rosemary.  It also was served with whipped & spiced lard ( which us carnivores devoured)   They also ordered squid ink paparadelle, with a lobster bolognese.  The sauce had been reduced to within an inch of its life, and  tasted of the coral shells, and aromatic veggies.   Spanish Mackerel -- was perfectly grilled and served alongside white beans, and a spicy celery type pickle. And last , but certainly not least,  Pork on Pork on Pork ( a must for any pork lover)   The team service approach was impeccable.  The hostess helped clear dishes as well as sat patrons. One might expect this type of service in a pricey restaurant, not a laid back, neighborhood, reasonably priced place like Cure.  Fresh silverware with each course, food came for entire table at once. Server and kitchen perfectly paced the meal , and our server explained the food on the plates, making it appetizing.  The kitchen is open , and you can see the professionalism as small portions of sauce were being prepared to order.   Cure runs like a well oiled machine.  You will be glad you came here.

RrcreGU3nYU4XEtCP1qxuw.text: I was visiting Pittsburgh from LA to celebrate my birthday with a friend. We visited several nice restaurants but she chose Cure for my birthday dinner. She chose the best one! From appetizer to desert, it was great. Food tasted so good and loved presentation!

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

pCKsoPcXaiVHRPb72HsKcg.text: Tune up your violin and sit back for this first world problem.  Cure was fine. It was perfectly ehh. Very expensive, hip, and into themselves. They do what every other small, expensive, hip place does. They offer incredibly small portions (almost rude) of what they claim is the absolute best way to do something.   In this case it is obviously the meats. However the slices are are so small that it is difficult to even fully appreciate. Everybody offers fantastic charcuterie boards these days. Was this one great? Yes, of course. But does it really stand out? Not at all.  The service was fantastic, the cocktails were good, the food was great, and it was overall completely forgettable.

7BiLBe1dnrSK1nTtqO0W-w.text: We had a great experience for a celebratory birthday dinner this past weekend. The food is always amazing and very delicious. The service is very good as well. It is a team effort there and everyone is very knowledgeable and made sure we had a good time. We'll definitely be back!

f-p0ZwUO5CUS9eSPO7ma7w.text: The small plate had nice options. We enjoyed the meat and mustard options along with the focaccia bread.

oDo9sZq_UurpkPLbUsRoyA.text: Cure, you little beauty you.  I took my momma for a tasting menu for her birthday, yes, she is spoiled, I know.  But you know what, it was worth it.  The food was delicious and the service was Pittsburgh style, friendly, honest, endearing and makes you feel right at home.  The only thing I disliked was the wine pairing with the tasting menu.  I felt it was clunky and didn't really enhance the food.  I let the hostess know this and she quickly had me try an alternate taste of something with the dessert which knocked it out of the park.  Please go, I am so happy to see a restaurant like this in Pittsburgh.  Cure is very similar to the type of restaurant I would find in the Bay Area, where I currently live.

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

QAwfA01dj_87pDwhkl8LAg.text: A vegetarian at Cure, an unlikely love affair: As a vegetarian, I had been foolishly ignoring Cure despite it being on multiple lists of trendy places to try in Pittsburgh. I thought there was no way it would cater to my dietary restriction based mainly on the name and concept, and also because it sort of smells like prosciutto inside. So when the opportunity to join some friends came up last Wednesday, I agreed to go simply to try out some of the drinks and see how they liked it. I had no idea I would be in for one of the best entrees I've ordered off a menu in a long time!   One thing I immediately loved about this place is that their menu allows for half and whole portions for most of the items. Perfect for all different scenarios- you usually don't finish a whole entree, you like eating half and taking leftovers, you like sharing multiple entrees without wasting, etc. Its all covered when you're able to manipulate your portion size. Great feature.   We started with a half order of the Bread and Butter which was great for three not-super-hungry people who were in the mood for a snack but nothing too heavy. The hunk of focaccia that came was fresh and delicious. My friends enjoyed the whipped lard spread while I loved on the olive tapenade. When it came to entrees I was surprised at how badly I wanted to try one of the pasta dishes, despite coming under the assumption that I wouldn't be eating. I took a half order of the Ricotta Gnudi and was blown away. A generous portion of buttery truffles were sprinkled on top of delectable homemade (??) gnudi and the pecorino blended in was the perfect final touch.   To be honest, this is one of the best entrees I have had the pleasure of consuming in Pittsburgh. The half order would have been the perfect size for a full dinner, but I took a little home to enjoy the next day and didn't regret it. Definitely one of the pricier options on the pasta side of things, likely because of the truffles, but absolutely worth it. For what it's worth, I would highly recommend this dish to vegetarians and meat eaters alike.   And to all the vegetarians out there like me, who felt a bit awkward about walking into a meat-centered dining experience, I hope this debunks your fears!

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Burnt Wheat Tagliatelle
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Ricotta Gnudi

qpv18n-XEi82_gOPdFGZKg.text: I had been wanting to try this place for a long time. When I finally did, this past Saturday night, it turned out to be a colossal disappointment. We started with the small salumi. It was good, fine. It was served with one piece of focaccia, which was not nearly enough to enjoy the pates and mustards.   I ordered the trout, which was cooked perfectly, but the main flavor of the dish was salt, with the secondary being bitter. It was literally one of the worse fish dishes I've ever had. It's hard to understand how this chef has received so many accolades.

XBSoZO8z_IVxmQgq7AEMUw.text: The star of Lawrenceville!! I am visiting from Philadelphia and decided to stay in this vibrant neighborhood.  My last night was spent having dinner at Cure.  It is absolutely top notch! Amazing attention to detail, food was perfect, service on point, comfortable and warm atmosphere...can't ask for anything more!!  Btw, only 3 seats are available at the bar.

MK1XmNMpvG0V92PjYxfB-Q.text: The food was spectacular!  So many tastes!  Best meal in Pittsburgh!  But, Clare, our  waitress.... couldn't have cared less about taking care of us.  We waited 45 minutes for the bottle of wine that we ordered. And even then the Chardonnay was room temperature. We asked for some bread for dipping and were told, " I'll ask."   $191.00 for 2 people for dinner. The food was worth it..... the waitress was lousy.

A5tAD4OHpMPGAnLaHUeROA.text: I'm happy to have eaten at Cure during my visit to Pittsburgh. Everything was top shelf, from the excellent service, quality of food and hip atmosphere. I wish I could have tried everything on the menu, but my favorite from what I sampled was the beef tartar. It's served with lettuce wraps and salt and vinegar chips to put on top. All the flavors complimented each other perfectly. I'm 100% recommending Cure to any friends that visit.

NCCrDgoVkS4ZI34TKDKueQ.text: Some of the best food in the city. One of my favorite dishes is the pasta dish. The atmosphere feels like you in a lodge and the service is top notch.  I highly recommend Cure.

KyAboebYL_KY34W8ve4d1w.text: Just went there for dinner. Service was okay, not bad but nothing amazing either. In terms of food, I had the raw oysters as well as the pork entree. The oysters were delicious and I really enjoyed them. However, the pork dish was a little too rare for me. I'm not used to eating medium-rare pork, and even though it was pretty good taste-wise, the texture was unappealing to me. I really had to slice the pork multiple times with the knife to cut the pieces apart (due to the stringy and rare texture), and honestly, at about ~$50 per person for just the oysters and the entree, I'm not sure I'd go back.

vLaisAJTEZcfp2Xrt8n0Ug.text: Justin's passion for technique is conveyed in the food. I have a new respect for his food and process.  This place blew my mind! I'm absolutely obsessed with the entire experience. The decor was rustic wood and amazingly creative from the  chicken wire & Edison bulb globe lights, meat hook coat racks, to the walk to the bathroom, through the kitchen!  We had the Fois Blonde and Steak Tar Tar. I cant even deal with how good it was...we had Strawberry and Spruce for dessert and I died. I want to marry this place...its my new fav and I havent had an entree yet.

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Had to snap the menu so I can plan my next visit!
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. This place is rustic and beautiful! In love!

M2ThePwYAntdycjzI97S8g.text: We had an absolutely amazing meal at Cure. The kitchen and staff were extremely accommodating with my severe dairy allergy. Everything was made to order and delicious. Definitely give this place a try. You won't regret it.

itBtaafOn2FCNfXB1tEuAQ.text: This restaurant was really neat!  I am not a vegetarian, but I eat many veggie meals.  This day I wasn't into eating meat, but I wish I was.  They have been awesome things to try here. My husband at the pork and loved it!  I had a pasta and some bread. It was also good!  The restaurant is quaint and small! Very Nice!

ACl3UAckCrAfkItXhM2HYQ.text: Welcome to great food in Lawrenceville, the Williamsburg of the Steel City.   This place has beautiful decor -- all wood everything with cool animal stuff and trendy people. The sulami is a must try, the beef and tuna tartares are insanely good, and the duck and trout are both fantastic entrees.   I'm close to giving five stars, but it's on the pricey side considering I've had 50 wings and 10 beers for ~$8 in this lovely city.

E-JM4idtq1LzJM1QL1G0Xg.text: I was looking for a good farm to table restaurant in Pittsburgh, and Cure popped up with some good reviews. The hostess was super friendly and so were most of the other employees we came in contact with. However our server, a young woman with a lot of tattoos, was extremely rude and abrasive. She just put a damper on the whole vibe of the restaurant with her poor attitude. The food was delicious, though.

JmBUJbQggVClUA0ZvcnivA.text: This is one of the best restaurants in the city. Interesting cured meats and other dishes expertly prepared by a chef who has been central to the exploding restaurant scene in Pittsburgh.   The space it beautiful. Industrial but quaint. Cocktails are delicious.   And for those who read the reviews referencing horse meat, it's not on the menu, never will be, and was brought in by some guest chefs from Canada for a one-time dinner. The grandstanders who state they will never come based on that probably don't know where Lawrenceville is located.    Do yourself a favor and judge the restaurant for yourself once you have visited.  If there is any restaurant I trust to have sustainably and properly sourced food, it's this one.

dk4VX2B0ICX8DmobzkSrpw.text: My husband and I ate here a couple of days ago and we are still dreaming about our dinner! For an appetizer, we split the Salami platter. The salamis are not only homemade but recipes from the owners grandfather. For dinner my husband had the spaghetti carbonara and I had the pork belly.   I have many food allergies and the waitress was super helpful in guiding me through the menu with recommendations and offering substitutions where possible. I have already been recommending this restaurant (all our Uber drivers now know this place :) and will continue to let anyone know and for anyone who is gluten free and/or Paleo this is a must!

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The Spaghetti Carbonara was pure bliss
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The Salami Platter had a range of being smoky, spicy and sweet!
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The Pork Belly was crispy on the outside and melt in your smooth on the inside

sXEFeVBje-p_FjXEUEbi_w.text: After finally getting to Cure again, I have to say this just might officially be my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh.  My friend and I were so obsessed with the small salumi we had last time that this time we ordered the large salumi. And we finished it all. Please don't judge us. Actually, I don't care. It's worth the judgement. This is a charcuterie fanatic's wet dream. The duck speck and the lardo are just ridiculously good, and thankfully those seem to be two of the staples that stick around on the menu. Even the pates were delicious, and I really am not a pate person.  We also got a salad, because that cancels out the fact that we just ate a table full of fatty meat (shush, it's sound logic). It had cinnamon croutons and bleu cheese and some other stuff. It kinda tasted like Christmas. I was into it.  We also got a main course to share. I know, I'm not sure why we thought this was a good idea. It was wayyy too much food! Next time I will (attempt to) control myself, but questionable decisions aside, I would have been super sad to have missed out on the cider-braised veal cheeks. Even better than the pork sampler I had the first time I was here, with the same simple, unpretentious style. Nothing fancy, just a whole roasted baby onion and some crispy kale leaves and an impeccably cooked piece of meat.  There's honestly nothing I dislike at Cure, besides the fact that getting in can be difficult on the weekend. I was turned away as a walk-in several times before finally planning ahead and making a reservation. But it's worth it!

-lqikAYrUllXRTx4pJZW8w.text: Chef Severino is the real deal.  Passionate, friendly, and completely dedicated to his passion.   I had the small solumi, Pork blood sausage  gnocci and cheese plate.  The food was perfectly cooked and prepared expertly.  I sat at the "kitchen table" and was able to watch the chef for quite a while.  He and his sous chefs worked well together and clearly knew each others rhythms and needs.  Chef asked me what brought to town,  what I liked, and I felt entirely like I was the only person there *though clearly I wasn't)... Already planning my next visit!

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pork Blood Sausage and Gnocci

YkKZnMU29IWuUCuNGu5rag.text: My boyfriend and I went to Cure.  We were really excited about another BYOB. Sadly, on a warm day, the restaurant is unbearable!! There are limited AC vents which cannot accommodate the crowd.  The couples beside us were both complaining about the heat when we sat down.  As the heat continued to rise, we decided to leave after the appetizer - 10 bites of cheese for $14!  We explained our discomfort to the waiter who told us there was nothing to be done - it is HOT on a hot day.  We left with 2/3 of our wine and paid the hefty corkage fee.  Since they don't make the cheese, they can't really take credit for it. So I can't rate the taste of the food, just the discomfort and overpricing.

zCrWmGFa6pJFRoSkMsX9eQ.text: My boyfriend and I ate here this weekend.  Made a reservation about a week in advance.  The whole experience was perfect! The staff was very attentive and knowledgeable about the food and drinks.  We had the large Salumi plate and a bottle of the La Bete Noire Malbec, perfectly paired and so delicious.  We also split a half portion of the Ricotta Cavatelli which was amazing.  We left feeling very satisfied.  I can't wait to return and try other items on the menu!

xltoSsR0hc8olOYuuLojxg.text: Disappointing  We decided to try this place because of the reviews,but unfortunately left disappointed. Despite a 5 pm reservation time , we waited 55 minutes before being served any food. At tat time there were only 5 tables (3 of which were deuces ). Then we waited another 45 minutes for the dinner entrees. Dessert followed 20 minutes after it was ordered . The food was innovative , but not as good as Salt. The Pigs ears Salad contained no Pigs Ears--surprising for a place that boasts it pork products. Then the Hostess or Maitre D had the audacity to ask for the table so , they could turn it over. We were not the rate limiting step in the dinner service. Would have gladly been out of there in the 2 hrs that they allot for service ,BUT WE HAD TO WAIT FOR SERVICE. If you are looking for better food and service try Salt of the Earth. Whatever happened to customer service?

I3T_XpW1QCq5yzNMtTKPJA.text: I went here last Sunday with my wife and we had one of the best meals we've had all year (and it's been a great year of eating).  Cure is the type of cozy, on-trend, local, seasonal etc. etc. type restaurant that you are seeing in most cities big and small across North America, but unlike a lot of its peers Cure backs up its style with a whole bunch of substance and the kind of laid back good vibes atmosphere that you can't help but love.   Now, we didn't try any of the charcuterie which is apparently good (and represents the place's namesake) but when you look at how interesting and constantly changing the menu of cooked dishes is, I can't rationalize ordering the charcuterie plate as good as it may be.  To start I got the heirloom tomato salad with pickled grapes, burnt onions, balsamic zabaglione, dill, taleggio fondant and really good crumbled sour dough. It was interesting, beautifully presented and successfully pulled together the really fresh produce very, very well.  My wife started with the fava bean and ricotta ravioli, which had an amazing tarragon pesto. The flavours were subtle (in a good way), the pasta was very well cooked and again the dish was really well plated.   For my main I had the hanger steak with smoked crispy potatoes, maple glazed carrots and maitake mushrooms. The components were meant to be eaten at the same time and they came together into this beautifully smokey, super manly dish that reminded me of cooking meals over a fire while camping. The smoked goat cheese that also accompanied the steak was interesting but not really necessary to the enjoyment of the dish. I only had a bit of mine but people that like goat cheese will probably go nuts for it.   My wife had the meat plate which came with a very rare, and super delicious squab breast, roasted pork belly and duck confit. These were all well cooked but the highlight was the middle-eastern spiced chickpea fritter, which on the menu seemed a little out of place in the dish, but on the plate was both delicious and surprising and actually tied in the meats quite well.   For dessert I had the blueberry soup, which was served with house made granola and a panna cotta. I wanted to like this but it was frankly just too sour, and it was the only miss on the menu. My advice would be to scale back the amount of the soup relative to the amount of panna cotta and I think you'll be left with a really fresh summery dessert.  My wife had the the chocolate souffle, which was light and fluffy and generally pretty textbook. It came with a very tasty pistachio butter and a few drops of vincotto (which is a thick, sweet Italian condiment that is made from reducing grape must and tastes like very rich balsamic but is not a vinegar). It was delicious.  Drinks-wise, cocktails were truly stellar, especially the one with bourbon and blackberry. Beer selection was interesting and reasonably priced.  Coffee was a bit weak, but overall decent.  The only other miss at this place was the wine list which was bizarrely priced relative to the menu and to the other drinks on offer (by-the-glass offerings were $12-15 and most decent bottles started in the high 60's). I would like to see this place get some decent cheaper wine options and to expand offerings on the new world cool climate wines (Oregon, New Zealand, upstate New York, Ontario) that are becoming increasingly recognized and which would in my opinion pair well with the type of food being served.  All in all, this was a great food experience and I will most certainly be back. I encourage Pittsburgh residents and tourists alike to check this place out and stick around to see all of the really cool things that are happening in surrounding Lawrenceville before or after dinner.   I wish the owners of Cure great success, they truly deserve it.  Rating: 4.5/5 - but this could easily be a 5 with a better wine list and tighter dessert offering.   -Brian   PS - for visitors to Pittsburgh, you may want to drive out here or arrange a private car (only slightly more expensive than a cab) beforehand as it is a real pain to get taxis to come outside of the city core on a busy night.

7QUqCxV98WKSbv57Tz6CUw.text: If I had anything to complain about it was only minor things. The place is a pretty far hike from downtown but it is well worth the drive.   The drinks were simply outstanding and the staff was knowledgeable about what they were pouring.   I ordered a dish called Gluttony that had all sorts of tasty bits. It was delicious. However, there was some foam on it that I'm assuming was for garnish but was very much overkill. It didn't affect the taste but it looked like someone spilled a red beer on it.   Totally worth the trip.

HmiBbiqLZprQtplrTtqh-A.text: After months of wanting to try Cure I was finally able to convince some friends to splurge on a great night out. Fortunately my hype was not an exageration, and everyone loved the restaurant and their meals.   We started with the large charcuterie board which was packed with 3-4 slices of about 10 different types of cured meats, several mustards, some great pickled things, and bread. It was a fun appetizer to share as everyone sampled the different cured meats then exclaimed "No, no, no, THIS one is the best." We split the app 3 ways, but it is certainly large enough for 4-5 people.   For my entre I had the dry aged ribeye which came with caramelized onion puree, parsnip puree, and berneise sauce. The steak was fantastic, cooked edge to edge at a perfect medium rare. The purees allowed you to mix and match tastes until you found your perfect combo. One of my friends had this duck confit/pork/beef ragu that tasted like the worlds best slow braised pot roast. My other friend had the the short rib with goat cheese risotto and charred/roasted brussel sprouts. It was a huge plate of savory/tangy/rich goodness, hands down the winning plate of the night. We topped the meal off with a great cup of La Prima coffee, and everyone was pleased.  All together we each spent $60 including tip, which was just the right amount of money to prove to my friends that it's absolutely worth doping a little cash once and a while for a memorable meal. Hopefully we will no longer be limited to $.25 wings, and $2 yuengs!

LPXqCT0WRdKSJ03zm_JptA.text: What an amazing experience. The food was just so delicious. I would love to go here again, and again. The portion sizes are about what I expected. Not very large, but you go here for quality not quantity.  If you frequent and enjoy places like Eat N Park, and Outback, this would not be the place to go. But if you prefer a great meal that is not mass produced I would certainly recommend Cure.

v5ll6h2EKjKCHAlWW7Dtaw.text: After trying to get reservations here for a few weeks, we finally visited Cure on a Wednesday night. The service was FANTASTIC. The cocktails were small but delicious. Their bread and butter appetizer with olives baked in was soooo good. We had the small salume--surprisingly, it was not the cured meats that tasted salty at all, but rather the sauces and pickled vegetables they paired with it.  The coolest part of Cure is the setting. You can see right into the kitchen, and it has a rather homey feel to it (despite the large taxidermied boar heads above). It is small and intimate, and perfect for an anniversary dinner.  The only reason I am not giving it 5 stars is because of our entrees. We both ordered pasta dishes--what I got was a dish of pulled lamb with a few small balls of pasta. I also have a very low salt tolerance, and found much of the food to be very salty.

oMrKqYvwm1abbjvZEynl1w.text: Pretentiousness ... Noise ... $$$ ... Meat ...  If these are what you consider to be the makings of a good time, then by all means give Cure a try ... If not, go elsewhere and have two or three nice dinners for the same price.   Ok ... I don't eat meat and I'm the first to throw darts at vegetarians who go to a meat restaurant expecting to be catered to ... But the harrumph ... The chef won't alter any recipes line is infuriating ... But I can ask him to throw something together. The something was a 1/2 cup of some sort of grain, some greens and just to say FU vege-person, a nearly raw egg on top.   I don't understand ... There were pasta dishes ... When you're about to throw the meat in ... Don't !  The music was so loud that everyone in the place was shouting ... Just didn't understand the attempt at ambiance. I couldn't hear any of the attempt at conversation ... Ears were ringing.   Expend to spend about $100/person.   Now I do have to say, the people I was with rated the food as excellent ... Some of the best in Pittsburgh.   From my perspective, the emperor has no cloths.

sPaE_UkR12n2yw3QEv9hww.text: Four for dinner, 6:00 pm, Sat. evening, 3rd try at a reservation. Pretty quite when we walked in, but soon the place was full. Our waitress was efficient and very friendly. During the course of our meal we had three people attend to us.  As others here, we started with the large salumi. Very interesting and a great start. Between us we had trout, pork cheeks, pork trotters, and beef. Pretty presentations, interesting ingredients. And all were quite tasty.   Deductions: our great waitress rushed us with our appetizer, taking it before we had finished it. Really. Had we lingered too long on this wonderful meat? From then on we were self-conscious about the time and wondering when we might again be pushed. We weren't, but it took a little shine off the experience.

KJzm7g6wzgcUQMa8owrWkw.text: One of the best meals I've ever had   Hands down. Poor service though.  I was treated like a second class citizen on the first visit but honestly I'm the person that is going to spend the money on a good meal like this!

SDIMqBiJZ9xIrsvtiw3qhQ.text: It is a very cute and quaint little restaurant! The food is very tasty, and very unique. I am a fan of their half portions, because I can only eat very small amounts of food at a time.

Jenov5DGZQCzKafxYRte9Q.text: Overall we had an enjoyable experience,  but I was just not that impressed with food.  Tried the small Salumi, beef tartare, and the duck entree.  We both liked the Salumi the most.  Perhaps my expectations were too high going in.  It is a cool place and the service was good, so I would still recommend checking it out.

H5y3tYg6vDK71ICNFSsBww.text: For my husband's birthday, my parents gifted us the dinner and round trip Uber.  I had been to Cure with my parents when we first moved, and Husband was working late. We had a phenomenal dinner, which included an outrageously tasty and original strawberry gazpacho and memorable drinks. Before the end of the meal, my parents had decided, and I agreed, that dinner would be a great birthday present for Husband.  I was so excited for the meal, and they seated us right when we arrived, at a comfortably table in the corner. The decor is the definition of rustic: wood floors, wood tables, and pig heads hanging on the wall. The waitstaff was attentive and friendly.  We took a few minutes to decide on cocktails to start, and ordered the tasting menu. My husband was a little weary of the unusual flavors, but I egged him on. Here is the menu:  ONE WAY TICKET TO FLAVOR TOWN  6 course tasting - 80 beverage pairing - 35 July 28th, 2016 SNACKS lardo - fermented radish, crostini nduja - Pecorino Romano, maple sugar, pine nut roasted oyster - bourbon bacon, mustard seed, grapes macaron - foie blonde, tea soaked prune duck tasso - strawberry soffrito, green cardamom pancetta tessa - cynar honey, pickled peppers* 2014 Ritter von Gluck Riesling, Rheinhessen, Germany SOUP roasted peach and brioche, black olive, catnip NV Vicente Gandia 'Hoya de Cadenas' Cava Macabeo/Chardonnay, Valencia, Spain ORECCHIETTE chantrelle, sweet corn, chervil, ricotta salata 2013 Val de Mer Petit Chablis Chardonnay, Burgundy, France HANGER STEAK burnt eggplant, crispy-smoked potatoes, padron pepper, caramelized onion, walnut, sauce "muhammara" 2014 Pierre Morel 'Luberon' Grenache/Syrah, Rhone, France SMOKED GOAT CHEESE MOUSSE apple cider marmalade, sesame streusel BASIL YOGURT PANNA COTTA blueberry consomme, hazelnut, lemon, hibiscus cucumber-elderflower spritzer *consuming raw or undercooked meat, seafood or eggs may increase your chance of a foodborne illness *please inform us of any allergies  The tasting menu is a bit cheaper than tasting menus in New York are, which made it feel a little less stressful and less pressure to enjoy. This was good, because, well, some of the dishes weren't as enjoyable as we had hoped.   The "Snacks" course was brought out before we were halfway done with our drinks, so we knew we would be rushed through dinner. The whole 6-course meal took a little over and hour and a half, and many pairing we rushed to finish before starting the next pairing, so we definitely were rushed. Some of the Snacks were delicious (roasted oyster, duck tasso), some were merely okay, and some just didn't work very well (foie gras macaron).  The soup was...interesting. Husband didn't like it at all, and didn't eat more than a bite or two. I finished it, but didn't love it. The catnip was extremely bitter, but not in a way that pleasantly balanced out the sweet peach. The brioche was not a shiny eggy bread, but a white gel at the bottom of the soup, which was delicious and an interesting texture. Overall, not our favorite course. We were later asked what we thought of the soup, since it was new for them, and I told them what I just told you. They took a little bit off the bill, which was nice and unexpected.  The pasta course was tasty, but not outrageous. The pasta was homemade and the texture was perfect. The sauce was remarkably corn-tasting, which was pleasant. We both finished our plates.  The steak was the highlight of the meal, The steak was perfectly cooked: crispy around the edges and red in the center. There was a baba-ganoush-style sauce on one side and a sweet caramelized onion sauce on the other. A bite of steak dragged through both sauces was memorably tasty and the highlight of the meal.  I enjoyed the smoked cheese and dessert, although didn't take any lasting memories from either. My husband was lukewarm on the cheese and didn't finish his dessert. The drink pairing from the dessert, however, was as wonderfully sweet, complex, and delicious as our starting cocktail, and ended the meal on a happy note.

SICed-QRrkpoO_hptmflPA.text: Dinner reservation 2/14/16 We wanted to go somewhere new for Valentine's Day and our 10 year anniversary, so we decided on CURE, based on all the great reviews we've heard and read. We are so glad we did! The location is a bit surprising, but when you walk through the doors, it becomes a whole new world. The service was phenomenal. Our server Cass, was friendly and knowledgeable. He made great recommendations to us and we decided on the 6 Course tasting dinner with the wine pairing. What a great choice! The progression of the food from the beginning until the end was a True culinary journey. Each food was better than the next. The portions were small (tapas style) but they were totally appropriate for the number of foods served. Chef Justin Severino is a genius! The combinations that he put together were unique and surprising all the while being absolutely delicious. We ended with the chocolate souffle and the citrus desserts. The perfect ending to a perfect dinner. We loved it!  Chef Severino was friendly and accessible, visible the entire time expediting and overseeing all the preparations. Gladly, but briefly conversed and shook our hands, and was very gracious hearing our praise.  A truly unique, exceptional and indescribable culinary experience. With service to match from the entire staff.  Cure!! Not for the average person certainly.  But quite remarkable. Ed & Susan

O-_PtCsWZI3rM8H409UfsA.text: No wonder this is one of the hottest places in Pittsburgh. It's reputation is well deserved.  We were a group of 5. When we arrived, our table wasn't ready yet, and there is no bar or waiting space (that was the only detraction). There also isn't much in the area, so we wandered around for 5 minutes, and then waited inside.  Once we were seated, we ordered the salumi and cheeses. Both were amazing - but the salumi doesn't compare to anything I've ever ordered in terms of charcuterie.  I recommend that everyone try it.  Three people in our party got a fish dish, I got pork with kale, and my husband got a dish called 'meats' - well named.  Everyone thoroughly enjoyed their entrees - absolutely no complaints. The dishes have creative flavor combinations and are extremely well prepared. I'd back in a second.  We finished off our meal with chocolate souffles - all very good. I'd go back in a second and wish I lived in Pittsburgh to visit more!

LmvWFokUSi4KTluK88iVDg.text: So disappointed.... Got there at 5:00 food wasn't served until 6:05! Overpriced, overrated & left hungry!

P_KPY5rC0l1qY9zKPcqySw.text: I was disappointed when I made my reservations and was told all that was available was the bar. After our experience with the Bartender and the two other folks we meet at the bar I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The bartender created some amazing looking drinks and entertained us. The Salumi plate is to die for. I had the pork chop and it was nothing less than 6 out five stars.  Great place and highly recommended.

F35u28H5rgoEHLl-wEI22A.text: Cure is kinda great.   They have a lovely booze list (and because it's Pittsburgh, there are a lot of choices in the Amaro category..)  Their apps were stellar (The Tuna Crudo was divine, the salad was a work of art, the salumi plate is 2legit2quit)  Their mains did not disappoint either (expertly finished risotto, fresh walleyed pike..great Morcilla sausage)  If I could add one gripe, and it's a tiny one at that- the main dishes are lacking in the salt department. While my pike was tasty, I was missing a salt element to truly finish off the dish. I noticed this with all other dishes as well.   That's it. Go here. It's awesome.

RfoV78WIm-5WtWnzkGEFAA.text: This place has nice decor, music and charcuterie items; unfortunately, that's about it for pros. There is a narrow wine selection for a "charcuterie" and the gnocchi plate was extremely salty and only contained about ten actual gnocchi (which were quite good, but overwhelmed by the rest of the dish). The meat plate is nowhere near to die for.  The sauces were unusually sour, the meaty flavors were dull, and some pieces were overcooked. Overall a big disappointment, given the comments here and the street talk.

fXI-Nau4zesmnqF1v-sb6g.text: I tend to hold restaurants like this to a higher standard. I'm pretty particular and expect a quality experience. Thankfully, I'm thrilled to say that Cure didn't disappoint. The space is small but still very comfortable. You can see the crew cooking in the open kitchen in the back. Menu items are listed on a chalkboard and printed to a piece of paper that is attached to a wooden board at the table.  We were a party of 6 and everyone enjoyed their experience. We started with a cheese platter as an appetizer. It contained three different cheeses (all locally produced), marinated dates, honey comb and grilled bread. It was a wonderful starter.  True to its name, this is a meat place. So don't expect a ton of vegetarian options. In fact, there was only one entree my friend could order. She knew what to expect and really enjoyed the risotto. I had the gnocchi with braised pancetta. The gnocchi seemed larger than life and was tastefully displayed in a hearty bowl. I would like to try the duck the next time I go back. Don't expect an abundance of food. Expect real high quality portions. Also, the place is BYOB.  My only complaint with the restaurant is how loud it can get. The ceilings are high and tin which causes an echo. Otherwise, I highly recommend giving it a try.

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cheese platter as an appetizer. Three different local cheeses, marinated dates and honey comb with toasted bread. Lovel

XJ6rmOQz5bgOF7JtQBKodA.text: You can't underestimate the pleasure of a knowledgeable waitstaff the first time dining at a restaurant of this caliber.  Our waitress was spot on with a menu of complex recipes, including the new entree, black cod, which was poached to perfection.  Her recommendations were unbiased, yet informative, and her explanations of the offerings were as detailed as the chef's preparations of each dish.  Very impressive all around, including the cocktails and dessert.

8jK9xR5pmsPWgoasSp67Jw.text: This retaurant truly showcases some of the best food that Pittsburgh has to offer. The decor has a very rustic "all-wood-everywhere" feel that somehow manages to be cool without being too pretentious. I highly recommend the foie blonde macarons as a small starter. The pate was light and paired nicely with the hibiscus and pistachio accompaniments. The squid ink pappardelle pasta was amazing (although decidedly un-photogenic, or i would have snapped a picture). The pasta was tender, the flavors were wonderful, and the chunks of lobster were much larger than expected. My only "complaint" was the size of the portions for the amount that you pay. The pasta was available in both half and whole servings,  but the half-serving (in comparison to most other restaurants that I've been to) felt more like a quarter-portion. If you are coming hungry, make sure to load up on all of their other offerings or spring for the full portion to make sure that you aren't left wanting more!

7PMJV4nVzLcX9x7PhYUpgA.text: The medium rare pork chops had me nervous, but I dug in and I am a changed man. Would I ever order that temp for pork chops anywhere else? Never. That's what type of place Cure is. They are creative w/ meats and it's an experience.   I went before they had a liquor license, with a bar now, I can only imagine it's that much better.   Bring a group and share a salumi plate.

_H72nOeoMiAXb7RdvxGx-w.text: Had the pleasure of having dinner here this past weekend for my wife's birthday.  Drove all the way from Michigan and boy was it worth it!  We ordered the tuna crudo and porchetta tonato for appetizers.  I liked the tuna crudo more because it tasted more fresh but both were good and complicated dishes.  For entree my wife had the walleyed pike and I had the hanger steak.  Honestly it was probably the best hanger steak I've ever had!  Seriously, the combination of the red wine shallots, caramelized onion, crispy leek, cipollini onion, cheddar cauliflower puree, and lobster bearnaise was the best combination I've had in a loong time.  The pike was also good with a nice seared crust.  Not to compare to meat and potatoes (which I know we did) but we had the pleasure of going there as well the night before.  Comparing the two, if you want a more hip young adult louder music type crowd then M&P is a good place to go (food is goodthere as well).  But if you want a more warm feeling dinner with awesome locally sourced food then I'd definitely recommend Cure!

GiGXsPhMEXMoIrsK7kHjBw.text: Cure has been getting rave reviews, even in places outside of Pittsburgh.  So I was anxious to finally go and see what everyone was raving about.  First, the dining room is somewhat small, but very inviting.   The newest thing is that Cure is no longer BYOB, they have added a bar recently and an excellent wine list.  Our wait staff was extremely attentive and the food was absolutely delicious.  We shared the artichoke plate and also the Salumi.  My entree was the Pork Gluttony, and my friend ordered the Walleye/Pike. This is a unique place to eat and I highly recommend it.

WzlpGuKfwzTG0CE3M6IYyQ.text: I would kill for a 3.5 star.  Loved the oysters liked the gnuddi didn't like the charcuterie board liked the duck loved the cocktail in the bottle  they buy the best quality oyster so you can get any better  the gnuddi was good i did like the bonito flakes was not a fan of the meat board, a lot was bland and boring the duck was a good entree and cooked perfectly service was good and attentive

az2G1rhURz3K6OjA1I25Aw.text: Our service was amazing! We had a lovely experience! We tried the tasting menu and the small salumi plate. We enjoyed most courses and the food was high quality. I am rating it 4 stars because I was not a fan of the oyster casino or the dessert course. Will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Starter for the tasting menu!
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Amazing salumi plate! I loved the lavender mustard!
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Oysters and beef tartare!

b_YNW0eS0Tsq4kGLE-mo0A.text: We FINALLY made it to Cure (week before we leave Pittsburgh) and thank God we did. Best restaurant I have ever eaten at, hands down. If M&P is my affordable, can go fairly often for really good food restaurant, then Cure convinced me it could be my favorite date night place ever. If we weren't moving.  The food is beyond delicious. Our meals were so perfect ... amazing ... etc. etc. David ordered the Meats platter and I got the Beef, Goat, & Pig Heart Bolognese. When they came out, my first thought was, "Gee, you don't get a whole lot for the price." Not that I need nor want a ton of food, but this looked tiny! However, after the first bite of my bolognese I didn't care. The meats were so rich and tasty and delightful and the pasta was cooked perfectly! I couldn't stop saying "Omg" at first. My bf's meat platter came with squab breast, duck confit, pork belly, chickpea frites, muhamarra, baba ganoush, harissa, za'atar, feta, and orange. There wasn't a bite on there that wasn't amazingly delicious (I don't have enough adjectives in my vocabulary to describe this food!).   When I first moved here I convinced David and his family that curing, brining, and smoking were absolutely the way to go with most meats, if you have the time and equipment. Cure just further proves that point. Cure takes a really great dish and elevates it to damn near perfection.  I guess I should talk about the cocktails, too. I think this is the first review where that part of the review didn't come first, though we sat at the bar for like an hour before we ordered food. Our drinks were very tasty, indeed, and the bartender - Colin - was nice and friendly. But seriously - dat food.  This is opposite of M&P or Eleven in that, at least at the bar, it doesn't really encourage hanging out and just sipping cocktails. Once the another couple came to the bar area (there's only 4 seats), it was rather cramped. Once we were done eating it was like, " ... Ok, let's go." But that's ok, I don't need to dwell in every restaurant. 5 stars for Cure.

OwP35pImdE_3AhfoICUlXw.text: Well, Cure continues to receive awards and pop up on "must eat" lists so we felt like we had to give it another shot.   The first time at Cure we took one look at the menu and knew some direction from our server would be needed and welcome due to the complexity of ingredients.  However our server was less than helpful, offering very little information beyond "that's good".  We ordered the Salumi which is a huge assortment of meats.  It was fun trying the different meats and we had little idea what we were eating.  The atmosphere was quite nice - cozy and quaint.  Overall we were disappointed on our first visit, but felt like we needed to take another shot at cure due to all the "buzz".  Second visit - we were seated at the bar which was a little cramped but fine.  Our bartender was also our server and took quite a while to attend to us even though we were seated directly in front of him.  Our drinks were very small and very expensive for the size, but pretty (if that's what you want in a cocktail).  We went with wine for our next round of drinks.  Our meal was OK - we just weren't getting that jazzed about Cure overall.  We had the smoked trout and the gnocchi.  We also got an order of beef tartare which was excellent - best part of the meal.  For dessert we had frozen creme brulee which in our opinion didn't really "work".  We like creme brulee to be "cremey" not hard.  Finally we had some coffee with hazelnut liqueur that was just bad.   So, overall we just aren't understanding all the hype and buzz surrounding this restaurant.

fMD0tYxnCLD68abcAspXLA.text: Let me just preface this review by saying I don't eat meat.  Fish, yes.  Meat, no.  My boyfriend was excited about making a reservation at Cure and looked forward to it all week. Me...not so much.  I was worried I wasn't going to find anything I would enjoy on the menu.  However, after our fantastic meal last weekend, I quickly changed my tune.  The atmosphere was what got me first.  Rustic and simple, with tables that resembled cutting boards and no-frills table settings.  It was dark, cozy, and perfect for a date night.  Next came our menus...a piece of scorched paper, attached to a block of wood with a rubber band.  Interesting.  I went straight for the fish entree, which that night, happened to be a swordfish conserva.  It was served with "squid ink spaghetti, lobster- San Marzano tomato sauce, Meyer lemon, bagna cauda, parsley, artichoke" and sounded fabulous!  My boyfriend went with a rabbit porchetta, which came with "almond, roasted garlic polenta, pickled fennel, pancetta, apple, lacinato kale."  These descriptions are taken from the menu, which changes weekly in order to reflect seasonal availability.  While we were waiting for our food, I couldn't help but notice the eclectic music playlist Cure had going on that evening...mostly indie, with some Wiz Khalifa jams thrown in.  I was digging it.  When my dinner arrived, I was surprised at the large portion.  Two nice-sized pieces of swordfish sat on either side of an equally large serving of squid ink pasta, topped with a tomato and lobster sauce.  The fish was, simply, put, amazing. The little bites of lobster in the sauce set off the saltiness of the squid ink pasta.  Any skepticism I had of enjoying my meal here was completely gone at this point.  Where I found my portion to be almost over sized, my boyfriend's was pretty much at the opposite end of the spectrum. Luckily for him, I was willing to part with a few bites of my swordfish.  We finished the meal with Cure's chocolate souffle cake, a moist and decadent dessert topped with peanut butter, sea salt, and a touch of olive oil.  A fantastic way to end a delicious meal.  Overall, I would highly recommend this restaurant to carnivores and pescatarians (vegetarians, you might be out of luck).  I love that this restaurant has such a committed focus on using local, sustainable, and ethical products in their cooking.  Also note that it a BYOB establishment, and I highly recommend making a reservation.

2Ci1554YWvzg_ysC50R0lg.text: Stop reading this review and go to eat at Cure right now!  Given that you're still reading, I'll give you the benefit of the doubt and assume Cure is closed for the night, so let me help you plan your attack for when they reopen their doors tomorrow.  There is a lot of hype about Cure. Some would say that kind of hype is just from people trying to justify paying $30 for an entree. NOT SO. Cure is all that and an extra large Salumi plate on the side!    A beautiful painted copper ceiling balanced the rustic wooden beams decorating the walls and the hot wooden plates our meals were served on.  Besides the menus printed on torn paper, the friendly staff, and the giant stencil pig spray painted on the side of the building, cure is an entirely unpretentious affair.  They cure all their own meats in house, which results in some of the most unique and intense flavors I've ever experienced.  Virtually every dish surprises, with low and high end fusions like pigs feet with lobster sauce and pig cheek and parsnip pie.  The steak and potatoes are the most well prepared you could find.  Yet, the wholly inventive daily specials did not end with the entrees!  We finished with the amazing cheese plate, smoked goat cheese doughnut, and an impossibly indulgent yet fluffy dark chocolate souffle cake.  I feel genuinely lucky to have cure in our city.  I'll go back every chance I get!

eINllqsTSXzCYgPIWr-YoA.text: Horrible service. Unapologetically wouldn't accommodate any dietary restrictions or gluten allergies.

jx-HvnBntqa7Lu-Oye5GBQ.text: Tried Cure yesterday for my anniversary, and was definitely not disappointed.  I loved the rustic, almost butcher block-esque decor.  For a small restaurant like Cure, it made it feel almost like you could be dining in the middle of the woods somewhere.    We started with the watermelon heirloom tomato appetizer and it was delicious.  I forget exactly what the crunch was in the appetizer, but it was a little spicy and that kick added a lot to the rest of the dish.    I had the Pork Loin Roast  and I was very pleased with it.  It had some fennel, a roasted (perhaps grilled) tomato under, some 30 year old balamic, and a corn polenta.  The pork was cooked perfectly, and the dish as a whole was excellent.  My only complaint was that the pork itself didn't have a ton of flavor, but with the fennel and balsamic it made up for it.    For dessert we split the dark chocolate souffle cake.  It was awesome, i mean it's a dark chocolate souffle with sea salt and a pistachio butter, tough not to be awesome.

5Z5EwvPchgFlJ5tu2IvsyA.text: I haven't been here in a year or so, but the last (and first) time I ate here, it was absolutely delicious. So many rich flavors, served in such a unique style - slices of meat and cheese on a cutting board. I'll have to go again soon so I can give a better review, but this place is at least worth checking out if you're even the least bit of a gourmand.

ocNLKvebPa6sD6nY7oj2Pw.text: Hands down my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh for two years running. Chef Justin Severino is a humble genius who took what he learned elsewhere and brought it home to his native Pittsburgh. What he has created is a magical mashup of haute cuisine and good old fashioned references to Pittsburgh's turn-of-the-20th-century ethic, working-class culture. It's not cheap but go for a special occasion, and take every out-of-town guest who visits you here in our fair city. Cure is the best of the best. You'll never have a better or more compelling meal.

XLTUaoj78h3GXOdUZs-1bQ.text: Gave us some sparkling wine for our Anniversary sweet.  Food very good.  Close seating.  But not to uncomfortable.

GlBcuEiAGmtI5dOcMQjGUw.text: My boyfriend took me there for my birthday this weekend. What a different kinda place!  It was really, really good. Everything was bursting with flavor. It's not a place I would want to go to more than 2 or 3 times a year, but for a special occasion definitely try Cure. If you're not much of an adventurous eater though, don't go here. But we are and we loved it!

hoUkN5JlPbzdzqdO2hLA2Q.text: The ambiance was great.  My friend ordered the cure special and had a variety of cured meats and pickled veggies.  I ended up getting chicken,  which I had to send back because it was a tad undercooked for me.  However they replaced it with their ravioli,  which I was super glad to have.  It had a ghee sauce and was delectably.

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cappuccino

6DCQJZY-Ff0F8Q_cO8187Q.text: Service is the best.  Menu is for the meat lovers of the world.  Go early on a Friday or Saturday or you will be out of luck.  Sasaphras drink was excellent.  They make it on site from roots, but I will order it next time "neat" without the creme and such.  Dining room is small but adequate.  Door to the outside has an entry way so you can sit by the door and not get clobbered by wind, cold or heat depending on the season.  Trout of fine.  The salami plate was excellent by most standards but I realized I am not that much of a meat person, or salami style meat person.  Fine dining to be sure.  I give 5 stars to include the food, the wait staff, and the ultra friendly manager that was there.  Get reservations early.  Go early.  And if you want to hang a bit, tell the manager ahead of time so they don't program the table away.  Tip generously please.  PS deserts were stunningly well done as was the espresso.  Next time I will start with espresso and desert!

479V_2D-3Gg6u4zTSVb0lw.text: We always go to there winter time to eat live oysters. They are so good. They change menu every week so you can enjoy new things but you cannot expect to eat again your favorites.

SkoSY9Bzpz5Hxdigk9LbcA.text: My wife and I started out our wedding anniversary weekend here at Cure on a Saturday night.  She has had this restaurant bookmarked for about 3 years and we were waiting for that right occasion to finally come.  It shouldn't have taken us this long to come here but it was so worth the wait!   I made a reservation for this day about 4 weeks prior and it was for 645pm.  We walked in and every table was full besides the one that was reserved for us.  It's a smaller sized restaurant so you feel a little squished at first.  There was a table of about 8 or 10 people to the left of us and they felt really close to us.  They were a large group and kind of loud.  Luckily they were about to leave and when they did it was a lot more peaceful for us.       We ordered drinks and then a Bob Marley song came on!  That was nice because we got married in Jamaica and we love Bob Marley's music now.  That was really cool!        We pretty much knew what we were going to order for our entree but we weren't sure what to get for an appetizer.  Their appetizers are under their snacks menu off of their A La Carte Dinner Menu.  We looked at the menu and we weren't sure what was what.  We asked our waiter about a few snacks and he described it very well to us.  We ended up ordering the Bruleed Halloumi from their Snacks menu.  I don't remember how our waiter described this dish but I do remember him saying cheese.  We really didn't know what to expect.       About ten minutes later a chef from the kitchen brought us our "Snack".  There was a Bruleed Halloumi for each of us on our own plates which was so awesome!  It looked really fancy and just outright beautiful.  He described to us the dish again and I was very impressed.  I love having that interaction with the chef.  You can see the picture from my review on how this dish looks but it tasted so good.  The cheese was delicious!  There were other ingredients in there like a golden beet, concord grape, and thyme honey that went really well with the cheese.  Just a great overall little dish.  I could have eaten ten of these!         We ordered our entrees next.  My wife ordered their duck and I got their Hanger and I asked for it medium.  They suggested medium rear but I still wanted medium.       The entrees came out at a reasonable time and the same chef from the kitchen before brought them to us.  He explained each dish and we were ready to dive in!  Again the presentation and explanation of the dish was great.  It made everything come together so wonderfully this night.  My wife loved her duck.  She is very picky with duck and she always compares it to her favorite duck at another restaurant. This was the best she said!  It was so good I started eating her food LoL!       My Hanger was great as well.  So tender and it was melting in my mouth.  I always know that portions aren't always that big in nice restaurants like this.  That's why we ordered a snack before and maybe I should have ordered another one.  It still was a good portion and it was filling for me.  I just didn't eat anything most of the day to make sure I was hungry for the night but I didn't need to do that.       I would have probably ordered dessert if we weren't going out to other places after this.  Cure is probably the best restaurant we have ever been to together.  Great restaurant but most of all a great restaurant experience for us.   The pleasure of our waiter and the chef bringing us our food, the presentation, and him describing the dishes to us made the difference.  I felt like we were on Master Chef!       One minor concern is if you do bring your kids to dinner here to be careful in the men's room if you have a son.  There is a picture of a topless woman above the urinal.  We saw a few kids there too so just be careful if you bring you son into the men's room.       I wish it didn't take us three years to come here.  We will be back and looking forward to have another great restaurant experience here.  Thanks Cure for making our Wedding Anniversary very special and memorable.

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hanger
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bruleed Halloumi
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. My beautiful bride enjoying her drink

Hxn2eZMfxQFIvs-fys3Ydw.text: I wish I could give Cure 10 stars.  Absolutely phenomenal!  We dined here for our wedding anniversary and to say the food was three Michelin star worthy is an understatement.  The atmosphere at Cure is tight, and on the loud side, but the decor is welcoming as were all the servers and chefs.    We started with a couple drinks.  I ordered an OLD PAL rye whiskey / kina blanc / cappelletti - 10.  It was nicely presented by our waiter.  The drink was tasty.  After perusing the menu a little more we decided on an appetizer of Bruleed Halloumi - 10 chamomile, golden beet tahina, concord grape & thyme honey, malawach..  To better explain the Halloumi is a unripened brined cheese made from a mixture of goat's and sheep's milk, which was bruleed, assuming blowtorch, with two dipping sauce and a piece of malawah a Yemenite Jewish fried bread.    As we waited we enjoyed the atmosphere and some conversation.    When our appetizer arrived the chef approached our table to explain what exactly to expect.  The interaction with the chef made the tasting so much more exciting.  And the presentation was beautiful.  I really expected the appetizer to be on one plate and given smaller plates to share, but no it was split into two identical portions.  PERFECT!  No arguments over who gets the last bite.  The halloumi was crusted, slightly warmed, and delicious.  The sauces were interesting.  I didn't care much for the Concord grape sauce, too sweet for my palate.  But the honey sauce was a nice subtle sweet to balance the rich cheese.  I am so loving this and we have just begun.   Our entrees arrived a little later.  Again accompanied by an introduction from the chef.  I ordered the Duck breast -30- cynar caramel, spiced cabbage, brown butter Asian Pears, cilantro, vanilla served on a bed of sweet potato mousse.  Oh my Lord I want that mousse recipe!  The duck was nicely seared to a medium rare, and every bite mixed with all the ingredients on the plate was astounding.  I could possible run out of flattering words to describe this place before this review is over, but that's just how wonderful this dining experience was.  The portion sizes were just right, leaving me satisfied but not stuffed.      Cure hit it out of the park, grand slam, clear the deck, raise the Jolly Roger, Elvis has just left the building, and scratch my back with a hacksaw!

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Entrees

2ZQWVV9s0wexsI51ACHBFA.text: Very unique and very small  It's a bit cramped in here but I like the fact that there are never strollers or children!a

zhLJAtGBxRv9OwkbYipuHw.text: Our entire experience was amazing. We went during the middle of the week so it wasn't overly crowded and our waiter was attentive, friendly, and truly made the experience even better. The food was unique and delicious with a great presentation.

AEgzBUtb7XoCeeoKLymYAg.text: Cure has been on my 'must-visit' list for a long time, and I finally got an opportunity to visit for my recent wedding anniversary. I am so glad we went.  First and foremost - your visit to Cure isn't going to be cheap. It's worth it, though, so it's best to go in accepting that you'll be spending a pretty penny on this experience.  We decided not to do the tasting menu on our first trip, as we wanted to pick & choose what we were able to try. We ended up trying a variety of things without having to spend as much as the tasting menu costs, though we didn't get to try as much as we would have with the tasting menu. I think if I were to do it again, I'd do the same exact thing. That said, the tasting menu does appear to be pretty eclectic and inclusive.  We started out with the beef tartare and the salumi board. The tartare was good and very new to me. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I'm glad we tried it! The salumi board was a perfect appetizer, but there's a lot going on and it's easy to get confused/overwhelmed with what you're eating.  We then shared the Pork on Pork on Pork and the agnolotti pasta. The pork was amazing (except for the ramp mustard, but I think that's just me!) and the pasta was a great choice for sharing. It was a bit rich for my taste, but sharing it gave me the perfect amount so I could appreciate it.  Everything we had was delicious and the presentation was beautiful. I especially appreciated our server, who explained the menu to us and then talked us through what specifically we were eating with both our appetizers and our entrees. She was thorough, friendly and professional and I really think she made our experience!   All in all, we'd definitely come back to Cure to celebrate another special occasion!

g3L5qmv8kkViJ-YLM2nAGA.text: Drop the attitude.  This is Pittsburgh where it's ok to be nice!  It's why we visit this town.  The young server leered at us as if we had interrupted her hipper than hip millennial gathering. Our 'pork shoulder for two' was a meager collection of blood sausages and pork belly with a small bit of shoulder - perfect for ONE.  The loud room with Chipotle-feeling seating left us shouting at each other and trying to find a comfortable position.  Suggestions:  First, be nice.  Second, be clear in your menu- don't describe a bunch of pork by-products as a Pork Shoulder for Two.  Blood sausage isn't for everyone.

0eqcmFe1srMEzYTx5tjgJA.text: SC and I went to celebrate our first dinner out as newlyweds. We made reservations ahead of time and confirmed allergies with a staff member. They didn't seem to be aware though; when we were ordering, the server did not seem to be aware of SC's allergies and we had to mention it again (This was the third time allergies were discussed; once when placing the reservation, second when the reservation was confirmed, and third while ordering). However, besides this, the service was really attentive. Multiple staff members walked around to see if guests needed anything, to clear off old dishes/utensils and place new ones, to remove crumbs on tables, and to explain components of each dish (I really like this last part because I can never remember all the ingredients listed on the menu!). We also mentioned we were splitting all the dishes so they were able to either split the meal for us (and give us separate portions) or give us extra dishes to split it ourselves.  We ordered:  -Salumi (small). SO good. We especially loved the leek ash & porcini salami for it's texture and flavor. The duck speck and ciccioli were also some of our faves. The accompanying focaccia was really soft and had great flavor. It didn't quite work with the nduja ("spreadable" salumi). Definitely taste the meats with and without the bread; it's a different experience! The Violet mustard was also really good (I hate mustard but this had a nice fig-gy flavor).  -This is Why You're Here. My fave dish of the night. What a fantastic combination of thinly sliced ham with maple notes, peach jam (that really tasted more molasses-y), and lots of basil!  -Ravioli  (half). Also delicious! Loved the crispy corn and walnuts! The pasta was made really well.  -Charcroute. SC's favorite dish. Pork three ways (pork belly, braised cheek, boudin blanc) which provided interesting textures and flavors.   -Foie Blonde. What an interesting dish! We've never had savory macarons before and this was such a unique combination. SC thought it was kinda like a PB&J twist. The mousse-like foie is super salty but pairs perfectly with crunch of the macaron and pistachios and the sweet of the hibiscus jam.   -Paw Paw Cream Pie. Reminded us of a deconstructed S'more. We've never had paw paw before and honestly couldn't really pick up what it tasted like. The textures of the cinnamon meringue w/ paw paw curd went well with the graham bits on the bottom. We thought the meringue had a little too much cinnamon on it. The accompanying concord grape ice cream was really tasty (SC and I were just recently talking about how no one ever makes grapes the star of dessert! And while this was an accompaniment, it was still really well done!).  Overall, really interesting flavor combinations and ideas; would definitely return!!

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Paw paw cream pie
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Foie blonde
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Charcroute

nDRHfjPH0EVgcIkUqvubfQ.text: Everyone raves about Cure in Pittsburgh. I had high hopes for the restaurant, especially after having a great experience at its sibling restaurant Morcilla. A friend and I dropped by on a weekday night to see just what makes Cure great. It is definitely an interesting restaurant, although some parts of my visit were just so-so. Overall, it's a good restaurant. It still needs a bit of oomph to make it a great restaurant.  AMBIANCE & SERVICE: 5/5 It's adorable on the inside. The waitstaff were very friendly, knowledgeable, and proactive in making sure our visit was a good one. The interior was tastefully decorated; the glasses and tableware thoughtfully chosen to match the ambiance of the space.  FOOD: 3.5~4/5 I had a hard time rating the food for this restaurant. Overall, I liked the food. I didn't love the food, however, probably because I found some of the dishes a little too salty. Here's what we had:  - Salumi: beautifully presented on a wooden board, the salumi plate is any meat lover' dream. Personally, I'm not a big eater of meat, but I liked the selection with its different textures, flavors, and meat varieties. Each variety of meat came in small, bite-sized pieces, which made it a great dish to share and to sample.  - Bruleed Halloumi: so... we did not know what Halloumi was, but we took the suggestion from our waitress and ordered this dish. We later learned that Halloumi is actually a cheese, with a firm-tofu texture. This dish was interesting, but its taste was marred by just a bit too much sodium in the sauce.  - Ricotta Cavatelli: we ordered half a portion of this pasta. This was my favorite dish of the night - I really liked the richness of the cheese. My friend thought it was a bit too salty, but I think it was just about okay.  - Fluke: the kitchen split our one order of the Fluke entree onto two plates, which was super nice. The fish was very fresh, and was topped with a fancy tartar sauce.  - Chocolate cake: and finally, we had one order of the warm chocolate cake to share. It was beautifully plated, with a dollop of pistachio butter for flavor. I really liked the consistency of the cake on this one.  OVERALL: 4/5 I enjoyed the flavors of the food, but most of the dishes could have scaled back on the sodium a bit. You should check out Cure, though, at least for a bite of that salumi plate (and its picture perfectness)!

Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. 1 order of the Fluke entree, split on to two plates to share
Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Salumi plate (duck speck, bresaola, pancetta tessa, finocchiona, toscano,  salami fernet, salami negroni, nduja, pate campagnola, ciccioli)

WxWJjLE5QpvIfIUeEtdtKQ.text: Only came here Bc Anthony bourdain recommend d it~ Service was really good! Waitress was really on top of filling up the water :-) as for food I think I just got full from how much water I drank and not as much the food that I ate, granted we only got a few dishes but even the meat platter for two was def not enough to feel full. Still, food is good and service was amazing! Good to come once in your life if you have the chance

MHl6MTvD1KjNWsvPmHXxEQ.text: Cure is a definite must go to in Lawrenceville.  Be sure to make reservations as the dining area is smaller.  We tried the tasting menu in one of our visits, and the chef did not disappoint.  Every course left us anticipating what would be next.

-TCMu6y1je1aRp3cqndZMg.text: Cure is a small and intimate restaurant located in the Lawrenceville neighborhood. It is focused on serving local food that are seasonal. In case the name and the logo weren't obvious enough, the chef is a skilled charcutier and his talent really shows through their small but original and refined menu.  I cannot recommend the charcuterie board enough. It featured a great variety of salumi served with small pickled vegetables. It was quite a delightful experience trying each cuts. I also liked their drink list; seriously, they had me at house-made sodas. While it was beautiful and complemented the meal well, I thought it was a bit too small and overpriced.  Overall, I've enjoyed my dining experience at Cure and would not hesitate to recommend it. If you enjoy a cocktail with you meal, be prepared that you will be ordering a few of them (due to their small size) and that they are costly.

photos.caption: Photo of Cure - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Large Salumi @ Cure

oGMC4P2d03Fr2dD7P4l8bg.text: Expensive and not enough food. Had Pork on Pork on Pork, and my mate had the trout. The servings are too small for the price. No salad, no muffins or bread included. The dessert was supposedly a 'pie' but it was more of a mish mash of cream, plum jam, some graham crackers crunched in, and a 'dallop' of ice cream. The taste of the food was very good, and they were extremely busy.   and oh yea..the red wine was average for $11/glass. Very cool place inside, though noisy, no parking other than street. Server was very nice, and overall service was good to excellent.

SF9VMcepgg7YYInlc6SzkQ.text: We are from Florida and staying at an Airbnb in Pittsburgh.  We saw Cure featured on a tv food show and bookmarked it.  To our surprise it is steps from where we are staying.  The menu is interesting.  Service spectacular and food devine.  We enjoyed a small Salumi, Beef Tartare, half orders of Squid Ink Pappardelle and Spaghetti carbonara. For  dessert a goat cheese snack. Go - you won't be disappointed!
